repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
The font is not applied when the font-family name contains spaces.

Solution:
Enclose the font-family name in quotation marks.

comment_data.body:
since we're already doing a table.concat below, perhaps it makes sense to do this there. instead of storing this "formatting" info in the `fonts` list (although it's short lived so doesn't technically matter currently)

    font = ('"%s"'):format(table.concat(fonts, '","'))
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1293,6 +1293,9 @@ local function opt_to_global_state(opt, title)
   elseif vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+') then
     table.insert(fonts, vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'))
   end
+  for i, v in pairs(fonts) do
+    fonts[i] = ('"%s"'):format(v)
+  end

comment_data.body: Generic family names (`monospace` here) must not be quoted because the browser recognizes them as font families. so, I think we should enclose specific font families in quotation marks before adding `monospace` to the `fonts`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   end
+  for i, v in pairs(fonts) do
+    fonts[i] = ('"%s"'):format(v)
+  end

comment_data.body: then we need to call that out in a code comment. also, what happens if the user has `monospace` in their `vim.o.guitfont` list?

comment_data.body:
When multiple fonts are specified in `vim.o.guifont`, they are currently being inserted as a single element. It seems we need to modify this so that each font is inserted as a separate element.

and, Is it appropriate to write the comment like this above the for loop?
```
-- Generic family names (monospace here) must not be quoted
-- because the browser recognizes them as font families.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   elseif vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+') then
     table.insert(fonts, vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'))
   end
+  for i, v in pairs(fonts) do
+    fonts[i] = ('"%s"'):format(v)
+  end

comment_data.body:
I mistakenly thought it was about specifying multiple fonts in `vim.o.guifont`.(A fix is necessary for the above problem.)
If `monospace` is specified in `vim.o.guifont`, it is treated as a regular font family name, resulting in something like:
```
{font-family: "monospace",monospace}
```
It is unlikely that a generic family will be specified in `vim.o.guifont`.

need to find a way to simplify all of this. too hard to follow currently

-    table.insert(fonts, vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'))

+      char = guifont:sub(i, i)
+      if char == ',' then
+        if char_pre == '\\' then
+          str = str .. char
+        else
+          table.insert(fonts, str)
+          str = ''
+        end
+      elseif char ~= '\\' and not (char == ' ' and char_pre == ',') then

comment_data.body:
Hmm... I thought about it, but I couldn't come up with a good implementation. However, using for like this might make it a bit simpler:
```
local str, char_pre = '', ''
for _, char in ipairs(vim.split(vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'), '')) do
    if char == ',' then
        if char_pre == '\\' then
            str = str .. char
        else
            table.insert(fonts, str)
            str = ''
        end
    elseif char ~= '\\' and not (char == ' ' and char_pre == ',') then
        str = str .. char
    end
    char_pre = char
end
table.insert(fonts, str)
```

comment_data.body:
IIUC this is splitting on empty string as a way to inspect each character? And most of the logic is trying to deal with escaped commas (`\,`) ? Why not use `vim.gsplit` instead of `ipairs(vim.split)` ?

This seems to work:

```lua
local fonts = {}
local prev = ''
for name in vim.gsplit(vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'), ',', {trimempty=true}) do
  if vim.endswith(name, '\\') then
    prev = prev .. vim.trim(name:sub(1, -2) .. ',')
  elseif vim.trim(name) ~= '' then
    table.insert(fonts, ('"%s%s"'):format(prev, vim.trim(name)))
    prev = ''
  end
end
```

-    table.insert(fonts, vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'))
+    -- Example:
+    -- Input: "Font,Escape\,comma, Ignore space after comma"
+    -- Output: { "Font","Escape,comma","Ignore space after comma" }
+    local str, char_pre = '', ''
+    for _, char in ipairs(vim.split(vim.o.guifont:match('^[^:]+'), '')) do

comment_data.body:
If we do that, `fonts` would no longer be a table, so I think it would be better to write it like this:
```
for i, v in pairs(fonts) do
  fonts[i] = ('"%s"'):format(v)
end
```
Does this look good?

comment_regular_data.body: /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/runtime/lua/tohtml.lua:1300:16: value assigned to variable char is unused
code LGTM. can you make the [test change](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30105#discussion_r1743845724), assuming it makes sense?
It seems there is no test for the case where `opt.font` is not specified and a font is selected from `vim.o.guifont`. Should we add that as well?

> It seems there is no test for the case where `opt.font` is not specified and a font is selected from `vim.o.guifont`. Should we add that as well?

sure but please factor out the existing test into a `test_generates_html(guifont)` function to avoid lots of duplicate code.

> factor out the existing test into a test_generates_html(guifont) function

Is this what you mean...? -> de1df14d1a5de2fdb3e06be1cd893320d4c09ef2

title: fix(tohtml): quote font-family names
